item.title: Ohio officer fatally shot after being "ambushed" by gunman, authorities say
item.description: Authorities are searching for a suspect accused of fatally shooting a 23-year-old police officer in Euclid, Ohio, on Saturday night.

item.title: Sen. Chris Van Hollen says White House has a "very low bar for what's acceptable" from Israel
item.description: Democratic Sen. Chris Van Hollen of Maryland tells "Face the Nation" that the Biden administration has set a "very low bar for what's acceptable" from Israel in a report on that country's use of U.S. weapons in the war against Hamas. "With respect to the delivery of humanitarian assistance, and the total restriction of delivery of humanitarian assistance since the beginning of the war - by not calling that out flatly and saying that there have been arbitrary restrictions put on it, I fear that we have set a very, very low bar," he said.

item.title: Transcript: Sen. Chris Van Hollen on "Face the Nation," May 12, 2024
item.description: The following is a transcript of an interview with Sen. Chris Van Hollen, Democrat of Maryland, that aired on May 12, 2024.

item.title: Transcript: Sen. Tom Cotton on "Face the Nation," May 12, 2024
item.description: The following is a transcript of an interview with Sen. Tom Cotton, Republican of Arkansas, that aired on May 12, 2024.

item.title: Here Comes the Sun: Julie Andrews and more
item.description: Ahead of Mother's Day, actor and singer Julie Andrews and her daughter Emma Walton Hamilton sit down with Jane Pauley to discuss their latest children's book "Waiting in the Wings." Then, Lilia Luciano travels to Colombia to see where so many of the cut flowers imported into the U.S. are grown. "Here Comes the Sun" is a closer look at some of the people, places and things we bring you every week on "CBS Sunday Morning."

item.title: Spectacular photos show the northern lights around the world
item.description: People from the United States and Canada to the United Kingdom, Poland, parts of China and Russia saw the northern lights this weekend.

item.title: Blinken says U.S. won't back Rafah incursion without "credible plan" to protect civilians
item.description: Following President Biden's confirmation that the U.S. will not send weapons to Israel if there is an invasion of Rafah, Secretary of State Antony Blinken confirmed on "Face the Nation" that the U.S. "will not support" Israel if there is a "major military operation" in Rafah in the "absence of a credible plan to protect civilians."

item.title: Open: This is "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan," May 12, 2024
item.description: This week on "Face the Nation," Secretary of State Antony Blinken joins Margaret Brennan as America's relationship with Israel faces a serious stress test this week, with a new U.S. report that says it is "reasonable to assess" that Israel violated international law in its war with Hamas. Plus, a story about how a group of special operations veterans helped a fellow service member's family get their mother out of war-torn Gaza.

item.title: Cannes set to unfurl against backdrop of war, protests and films
item.description: The Cannes Film Festival rarely passes without cacophony but this year's edition may be more raucous and uneasy than any edition in recent memory.

item.title: Nature: Mustangs in South Dakota
item.description: We leave you this Sunday morning with mustangs at the Black Hills Wild Horse Sanctuary in South Dakota. Videographer: Kevin Kjergaard.

item.title: A mother's love, returned
item.description: For Peggy Means of Dowagiac, Mich., Mother's Day was just another "X" on the calendar, just another day without her daughter, Jennifer, who in 2017 was critically injured in a car crash before slipping into a coma. But Means refused to let doctors take Jennifer off life support. Steve Hartman reports on why Means finally can celebrate Mother's Day.

item.title: Bill Maher on not pulling punches
item.description: The host of the HBO series "Real Time," and author of the new book, "What This Comedian Said Will Shock You," doesn't discriminate between right and left when aiming his barbs at tribal politics.

item.title: Bill Maher on humor in politics: "Don't be tribal"
item.description: Comedian Bill Maher, host of the HBO series "Real Time," doesn't discriminate between right and left when aiming his barbs at tribal politics. He talks with CBS News chief election & campaign correspondent Robert Costa about gladly courting controversy, whether by mocking politicians or inviting them to his show. He also discusses his new book, "What This Comedian Said Will Shock You."

item.title: "Mammoni" | 60 Minutes Archive
item.description: In 2001, 60 Minutes reported on "mammoni," Italian mama's boys who, well into adulthood, lived at home, slept in their childhood bedrooms, and were waited on by their mothers. At the time, one 39-year-old called the set-up "paradiso."

item.title: Fashion double-takes from the Met Gala
item.description: Correspondent Faith Salie reports on fashion's biggest night, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute Benefit, where designs ranged from artful flowers to artfully positioned sand.

item.title: How biopic "Back to Black" puts Amy Winehouse "right back in the center of her story"
item.description: A new movie dramatizes the life and music of the charismatic British singer whose struggles with drugs and alcohol led to her death at age 27. Director Sam Taylor-Johnson and actress Marisa Abela describe capturing a complex life on film.

item.title: "Back to Black": The life of Amy Winehouse
item.description: A new movie dramatizes the life and music of British singer Amy Winehouse, the charismatic, multiple-Grammy-winner whose struggles with drugs and alcohol led to her death at the age of 27. Correspondent Seth Doane talks with director Sam Taylor-Johnson about capturing a complex life on film; and with actress Marisa Abela, who describes how she inhabited the role of Winehouse from the inside out.

item.title: Josh Seftel's mom on the perfect Mother's Day
item.description: Just in time for Mother's Day, filmmaker Josh Seftel catches up with his mom, Pat, for some timely advice on the holiday.

item.title: Meet Stan Herman, elder statesman of American fashion
item.description: He's the most prolific fashion designer you've never heard of, and while he may not be a household name, Stan Herman has dressed millions of households, and has also designed uniforms for a multitude of companies, from TWA and Avis to McDonald's and FedEx. Correspondent Alina Cho talks with the 95-year-old Herman, who recently recounted his extraordinary career in the memoir, "Uncross Your Legs: A Life in Fashion."

item.title: Passage: In memoriam
item.description: "Sunday Morning" remembers some of the notable figures who left us this week, including "B-movie" director Roger Corman, whose production company helped launch the careers of such filmmakers as Francis Ford Coppola, Martin Scorsese and James Cameron.

item.title: Thousands of Canadians forced to evacuate as massive wildfire burns
item.description: The blaze in northeastern British Columbia started Friday and almost doubled in size by the following day, reaching about 4,200 acres.

item.title: Tony-nominee Sarah Paulson: "If this is a dream, I don't wanna wake up"
item.description: The actress, starring in the comedy-drama "Appropriate," talks about how her mother helped set the stage for her dream of acting; and why she still hasn't watched herself in "American Crime Story: The People vs. O.J. Simpson."

item.title: Roger Corman, "King of the B Movies" 1926-2024
item.description: A look back at the hallowed career of the indie "B-movie" filmmaker, known for exploitation films, monster flicks, and some bizarre movie posters.

item.title: Tony-nominee Sarah Paulson on "Appropriate"
item.description: Emmy-winning actress Sarah Paulson has been nominated for a Tony Award for her performance in the comedy-drama "Appropriate," about siblings torn apart by unearthed secrets. She talks with correspondent Tracy Smith about how her mother accommodated Paulson's passion for acting, and why she still hasn't watched herself in "American Crime Story:" The People vs. O.J. Simpson."

item.title: Transcript: Secretary of State Antony Blinken on "Face the Nation," May 12, 2024
item.description: The following is a transcript of an interview with Secretary of State Antony Blinken that aired on May 12, 2024.

item.title: Saying goodbye to "Young Sheldon"
item.description: With the hit series wrapping after seven seasons, "Sunday Morning" talks with star Iain Armitage; Jim Parsons (who created the character of Sheldon Cooper on "The Big Bang Theory"); and producers Steve Molaro and Steve Holland, about the family comedy's success.

item.title: Iain Armitage on the final season of "Young Sheldon"
item.description: Iain Armitage, star of the CBS comedy "Young Sheldon," has pulled off a magic trick: helping carry a network TV hit for seven seasons while also growing up. Luke Burbank talks with the young actor about the show's finale; and with Jim Parsons (who created the character of Sheldon Cooper on "The Big Bang Theory") and executive producers Steve Molaro and Steve Holland about the show's success, which has surprised even them.

item.title: See stunning paper floral displays
item.description: They may not have much fragrance, but they look startlingly real and will never wilt or fade. Correspondent Conor Knighton talks with artists who create pristine peonies and pansies, life-like lilacs, and ridiculously large roses, using little more than paper, paint and glue.

item.title: Almanac: May 12
item.description: "Sunday Morning" looks back at historical events on this date.

item.title: Flash floods in northern Afghanistan leave hundreds dead and missing
item.description: Victims of the devastating floods in northern Afghanistan are burying the dead and looking for the loved ones still missing.
